briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 22, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Accelerating Climate Crisis, Global Warning Bells
sections.content: News gathered today clearly demonstrates that the climate crisis is no longer a distant future problem, but a severe and ongoing threat. In the Southern Hemisphere, climate disasters are becoming a reality, with record-breaking heatwaves leading to wildfire emergencies [2]. Internationally, reports indicate that the surge in AI data centers in the UK threatens climate change targets [29], and an analysis suggests that climate change impacts high winter Air Quality Index (AQI) levels in cities [36]. These reports align with warnings that ignoring climate change endangers our future generations and has devastating effects on the lives of sled dogs [33, 35], demonstrating that the climate crisis is intensifying as a global phenomenon beyond specific regions.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic Carbon Neutrality Practices, Active Participation from Local Communities and Businesses
sections.content: Various local governments and institutions across the country are making concrete efforts to achieve carbon neutrality. Cities like Gyeongju, Pohang, and Gimcheon are actively recruiting participants for the 'Carbon Neutrality Points (Automobile)' program, which offers cash rewards for reducing vehicle mileage [3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12, 15]. Jinju City and Daejeon's Daedeok-gu are accelerating efforts to achieve the 2050 carbon neutrality goal by actively promoting climate response in citizens' daily lives [10, 14]. Furthermore, Eumseong-gun Agricultural Technology Center is offering free soil testing services for 'carbon-neutral agriculture' [7], and collaborations such as between Korea Gas Corporation and Changwon Fatima Hospital for carbon neutrality implementation are underway [11]. Lectures aimed at strengthening carbon neutrality practices are also being held in the business and academic sectors [13], indicating expanding participation across society.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition, Domestic and International Cooperation and Technological Innovation
sections.content: The transition to renewable energy is gaining attention as a key driver for a sustainable future. Hanwha Ocean is accelerating its renewable energy projects, including offshore wind power [16], and local efforts continue with various municipalities like Yangpyeong-gun and Gochang-gun promoting integrated renewable energy support projects and holding explanatory sessions to expand their adoption [18, 21, 26]. Notably, Hankook Tire's Hungarian plant has signed a long-term renewable energy Power Purchase Agreement (PPA), contributing to an annual reduction of 10,000 tons of greenhouse gas emissions and the achievement of its '2050 Net Zero' goal [19, 22, 23, 25]. Efforts are also being made to increase efficiency through technological innovation, including discussions on integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enhance renewable energy acceptance [20]. Furthermore, private sector cooperation is active, with organizations like the Korean Veterans Association of Vietnam War and Jungbu Renewable Energy Co., Ltd. signing a strategic Memorandum of Agreement (MOA) to vitalize solar power installation projects [27].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Challenges in Climate Change Adaptation and Energy Transition Systems
sections.content: The impacts of climate change are already causing direct damage to the domestic agricultural sector, with Jangsu-gun promoting facility support projects to reduce orchard damage and seeking a new turning point for the apple industry [1]. Meanwhile, as the era of renewable energy dawns, concerns about the Korean-style Electricity Management System (K-EMS) have persisted for over a decade, indicating an urgent need for system improvements to ensure a stable energy transition [28]. In the business community, SK Chairman Chey Tae-won, who was an ESG advocate, has experienced a 'change of circumstances' by mentioning 'energy shortages' [24], highlighting the complex challenge of finding a balance between climate change response and energy security. This suggests complex challenges that must be addressed in the process of climate crisis adaptation and energy system transition.

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlights the severity of the climate crisis, alongside the simultaneous domestic and international efforts underway to overcome it. Continued attention and effort are required, and we look forward to seeing you again at the next briefing. This concludes today's climate briefing.
